facts.text: General election to the Municipal Board of Bareilly held in October 1953.
Appellant Mangoo Singh and respondent No. 3 Imdad Husain were candidates from Ward No. 15.
Date fixed for filing nominations: October 5, 1953.
Date for scrutiny of nominations: October 7, 1953.

Both appellant and respondent No. 3 filed nominations on due date. Imdad Husain objected to appellant's nomination on ground of disqualification under cl. g of s. 13-D of the Act due to arrears in municipal tax exceeding one year's demand.
Objection dismissed by Assistant Returning Officer; appellant's nomination accepted.
Counting of votes on October 29, 1953. Four persons to be elected from Ward No. 15; appellant third in list and declared elected; Imdad Husain fifth.
Appellant paid Rs. 115-3-0 on October 10, 1953, five days after nomination filing date.
Imdad Husain filed election petition to set aside appellant's election, including ground of disqualification under cl. g of s. 13-D.

Election Tribunal by judgment dated October 20, 1954, held appellant in arrears exceeding one year's demand to which s. 166 applies, disqualified under cl. g s. 13-D; payment on Oct 10 did not wipe off disqualification; no benefit of second proviso to s. 13-D.
Election Tribunal found no bill presented under s. 166 or demand notice served under s. 168.
Election Tribunal allowed petition, set aside appellant's election, declared casual vacancy under cl. a sub-s. 2 s. 25 of the Act.
Casual vacancy filled by election of third respondent on April 5, 1955.
Appellant filed writ petition under Art. 226 in Allahabad High Court; dismissed by single judge (Chaturvedi J.) on December 10, 1954.
Appeal to Division Bench (Agarwala and Sahai JJ.) dismissed on August 30, 1955.
High Court granted certificate under Art. 133(1)(c) on February 3, 1956.
Next general election due in October 1957.

legal_issues.text: True scope, meaning and effect of cl. g of s. 13-D of the U. P. Municipalities Act, 1916.
Relevant date for operation of disqualification under cl. g s. 13-D: date of nomination or date of poll?
Whether payment of arrears after nomination filing date but before poll wipes off disqualification under second proviso to s. 13-D.
Meaning of 'to which s. 166 applies' and 'demand' in cl. g s. 13-D: requires presentation of bill under s. 166 and demand notice under s. 168?

petitioner_arguments.text: Disqualification under cl. g s. 13-D operates on date of poll, as person is 'chosen' when voters vote; payment on Oct 10, 1953 before poll removed arrears.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: cl. g s. 13-D; expression 'for being chosen as'

petitioner_arguments.text: Second proviso makes disqualification transient, ceasing as soon as arrears paid; payment on Oct 10 wiped it off completely before poll.
'to which s. 166 applies' requires bill presented under s. 166; 'demand' requires notice under s. 168; neither done, so no disqualification.

respondent_arguments.text: Appellant disqualified on date of nomination filing due to arrears exceeding one year's demand; payment after did not remove it.

court_reasoning.text: Expression 'disqualified for being chosen as' means disqualification attaches at nomination stage, as election is continuous process starting with nomination; Returning Officer scrutinizes for such disqualification under para 22(2) of U.P. Municipalities Conduct of Election Order, 1953.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Nomination is integral part of election; disqualification on nomination date prevents being chosen.

court_reasoning.text: Second proviso does not have retrospective effect; disqualification subsisting on nomination date not wiped off by subsequent payment.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Payment after nomination does not erase disqualification existing on nomination date.

court_reasoning.text: 'to which s. 166 applies' describes nature of dues (taxes etc. recoverable under Chapter VI); does not require bill presentation or demand notice; 'demand' means amount due, not formal notice.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No need for s.166 bill or s.168 notice for disqualification to apply.

holdings.text: Appellant disqualified under cl. g s. 13-D on nomination date due to arrears exceeding one year's demand; payment thereafter did not remove it; no requirement of bill or demand notice.

precedents_cited.case_name: Chatturbhuj Vithaldas Jasani v. Moreshwar Parashram
precedents_cited.relevance: Disqualification under similar expression in s.7 Representation of People Act attaches at nomination stage; election continuous process.

precedents_cited.case_name: N. P. Ponnuswami v. Returning Officer, Namakkal Constituency
precedents_cited.relevance: Election continuous process; nomination integral part.
Cannot shake off pre-existing disqualification by subsequent payment or acquisition of right after nomination.
Disqualified at nomination cannot stand; leads to uncertainty if disqualification removed later.

statutes_cited.name: U. P. Municipalities Act, 1916
statutes_cited.relevance: Disqualification for arrears exceeding one year's demand to which s.166 applies; ceases on payment per proviso; applied to bar nomination.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Certificate for appeal; writ jurisdiction; similar disqualification expression.

statutes_cited.name: Representation of the People Act, 1951
statutes_cited.relevance: Similar expression 'disqualified for being chosen' interpreted.

statutes_cited.name: U. P. Municipalities (Conduct of Election of Members) Order, 1953
statutes_cited.relevance: Returning Officer scrutinizes nominations for disqualification for being chosen.

outcome.summary: Appeal dismissed; Election Tribunal rightly held appellant disqualified under cl. g s. 13-D on nomination date; election set aside validly.

key_quotes.text: 'shall be disqualified for being chosen as... The choice is made by a series of steps starting with the nomination and ending with the announcement of the election.'
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Defines relevant date for disqualification as nomination stage.

key_quotes.text: The wiping off of the disqualification under the second proviso has no retrospective effect.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Payment after nomination does not cure prior disqualification.

key_quotes.text: 'to which s. 166 applies' merely describes the nature of the demand referred to in cl. g.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: No requirement for bill or notice; clarifies scope of disqualification.
